channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: What About Sepp Blatter? Questions About the FIFA Case
item.description: Questions remain after the arrests of several high-ranking members of soccer’s governing body. Here’s what you need to know about the charges and the accused.
item.category: Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football (CONCACAF)
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: FIFA, a multibillion-dollar organization that governs soccer but has been plagued by accusations of bribery for decades, had several top officials arrested early Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With New Resorts, Macau Places Its Bets on the Chinese Middle Class
item.description: New resorts aim to continue the former Portuguese colony’s transformation into a Chinese middle-class tourism center.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lion dancers performing at the opening of Galaxy Macau Phase II on Wednesday.

item.title: After Indicting 14, U.S. Vows to End Graft in FIFA
item.description: Hours after indicting 14 people, the Justice Department and prosecutors for the Eastern District of New York pledged to rid the international soccer organization of systemic corruption.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD and MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: Jack Warner, a former FIFA vice president, is among those expected to face charges in the United States.

item.title: Medical Need Climbs Alongside Death Toll in Yemen
item.description: Some 8.6 million people, or about a third of the country’s population, were in “urgent need of medical help,” the World Health Organization warned.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED ALI KALFOOD and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Abdel Rahman Abdallah/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Yemenis were taken to a hospital after they were wounded during shelling Wednesday in Taez.

item.title: Obama’s Chief Negotiator in Iran Nuclear Talks Plans to Depart After Deadline for Deal
item.description: With the departure of Wendy R. Sherman, all the top negotiators on Iran since 2013 will have left the administration, leaving questions about who will help carry out a deal if one is struck.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Wendy R. Sherman in 2013. Her decision leaves questions about who will help carry out a final pact if one is reached.

item.title: Russian Political Activist Is Hospitalized With Mysterious Illness
item.description: Vladimir Kara-Murza’s role as an opposition activist raised suspicions of poisoning, but there was no confirmation of this from doctors or the authorities.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: H.I.V. Treatment Should Start at Diagnosis, U.S. Health Officials Say
item.description: Federal health officials announced the new guidelines after a clinical trial showed pronounced benefits for people put on antiretroviral drugs as soon as they learned they were infected.
item.category: National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Disease
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Pills were prepared for H.I.V. patients in Thailand in February. A major study found early treatment for people with H.I.V. cut down on the number of deaths.

item.title: European Union Asks Member Countries to Accept Quotas of Migrants
item.description: The appeal by the European Commission is a response to fears that southern countries will be overwhelmed by the influx of people crossing the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A boat with migrants, thought to be Afghans, arrived on the Greek island of Kos on Wednesday after crossing the Aegean Sea from Turkey.

item.title: A Region’s Soccer Strongmen Are Facing a Hard Fall
item.description: A case in which 14 senior sports officials and executives across the Americas have been charged offers a glimpse into the sort of deals that have long come under fire but have rarely led to a criminal proceeding.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: José Maria Marin of Brazil is among 14 from the Americas charged in a bribery and kickback scheme.

item.title: Al Qaeda’s Branch in Syria Denies Planning Attacks Abroad
item.description: The leader of the Nusra Front said in a television interview that Al Qaeda had ordered it to keep its focus on toppling President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Liao Ran on the Trial of Zhou Yongkang and China’s New Gang of Four
item.description: Liao Ran, a corruption analyst at Transparency International, discusses the fall of Zhou Yongkang, China’s former security chief, and the consolidation of power by President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times

item.title: Armed With Google and YouTube, Analysts Gauge Russia’s Presence in Ukraine
item.description: An independent report that draws on publicly available videos, photographs and satellite images has concluded that Russia is continuing to conduct military operations inside Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Indians Urged to Stay Indoors as Sweltering Heat Kills More Than 1,300
item.description: Most of the deaths were reported in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana in southern India, as temperatures surpassed 116 degrees in some places.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Asphalt on the roads of New Delhi melted amid soaring temperatures.

item.title: U.S. Rebukes China on Efforts to Build Artificial Islands
item.description: Comments left little doubt that Washington shared the concerns of other Asian nations about China’s growing military presence in disputed areas of the South China Sea.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Jinghong Journal: China’s High Hopes for Growing Those Rubber Tree Plants
item.description: With rubber prices at a 10-year low and farmers panicked over sinking incomes, officials say they have a rare opportunity to promote ideas to make the rubber industry more economically and environmentally sustainable.
item.dc:creator: BECKY DAVIS
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers collected the timber of unproductive rubber trees near Tuanjie, in southern China. A program aims to make the industry more sustainable.

item.title: Sunnis Fleeing ISIS Find Few Doors Open Elsewhere in Iraq
item.description: Many Iraqi Shiites are looking with distrust at Sunni civilians displaced by attacks by Sunni militants in the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Iraqi civilians fleeing fighting in Ramadi crossed the Bzebiz Bridge, which offers passage into Baghdad from Anbar Province.

item.title: A Wartime Bomb, Unearthed in Germany, Recalls Darker Days
item.description: Unexploded ordnance, covered over in haste or in oversight, is cause for alarm — and for wide-scale evacuations — long after World War II.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Residents lined up outside an evacuated nursing home in Cologne, Germany, on Wednesday, waiting for a World War II-era bomb to be defused.

item.title: FIFA Arrests Come at a Time of Continued Swiss Cooperation
item.description: Switzerland, famously secretive, has gradually become more cooperative with foreign authorities as its banking sector and companies seek to expand and flourish abroad.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Outside FIFA headquarters in Zurich on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia Says FIFA Corruption Investigation Is No Threat to 2018 World Cup
item.description: Officials said the arrests of top FIFA officials would not derail Russia from hosting the World Cup in 2018.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Construction continued Wednesday on a soccer stadium in St. Petersburg, Russia, that is scheduled to host some of the 2018 World Cup matches.

item.title: Ruling Party in Ethiopia Appears Headed for Sweeping Victory
item.description: Preliminary results show the incumbent Ethiopian People’s Revolutionary Democratic Front and allies winning 442 of the 547 constituencies, including all of Addis Ababa.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN
